newsitem.title: CHINA: GDP of China's five SEZs seen up 15 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: GDP of China's five SEZs seen up 15 pct in 1997.

text.p: The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of China's five Special Economic Zones (SEZs) is expected to rise 15 percent this year, an official of the cabinet's SEZ Office said on Thursday.

The GDP of the SEZs totalled 215.5 billion yuan ($26.0 billion) in 1996, up 14.3 percent from 1995, the official said by telephone. The growth rate was five percentage points higher than China's GDP growth rate.
The five SEZs are Shenzhen, Zhuhai and Shantou in southern Guangdong province, the southernmost province of Hainan and the southeastern city of Xiamen.
Their combined industrial output value topped 227.2 billion yuan in 1996, he said. The industrial output of Shenzhen alone reached 106.2 billion yuan, up 18 percent from 1995.
Their exports totalled 30.7 billion yuan in 1996, an increase of 3.4 percent compared with 1995, while imports slipped 1.1 percent to 27.5 billion yuan in 1996, he said.
